instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 19.5V 2.5A won't boot
threads.message:
Small liquid on <CAPACITOR>C6553</CAPACITOR>

When all connected go 19.5V and 2.5A on charger.
No fan spin, no chime, trackpad no clicks.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.56V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> = 12.56V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.41V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_OTH5V</SIGNAL> = 12.56V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_OTH3V3</SIGNAL> = 12.60V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S4_HS_TPAD</SIGNAL> = 12.60V

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> = 0V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.32V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 3.32V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> = 0V

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> is missing.

Found a bit of liquid which gone under <CHIP>U1100</CHIP>.
Is there any point of re-hot of <CHIP>U1100</CHIP>?

Any hints?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 19.5V 2.5A won't boot
threads.message:
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> (at same time).
If detected, check for pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 19.5V 2.5A won't boot
threads.message:
No pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.
It stays at stable 0.367V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 19.5V 2.5A won't boot
threads.message:
It MUST be steady high; unless <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is triggered.
Check <RESISTOR>R1210</RESISTOR>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 19.5V 2.5A won't boot
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R1210</RESISTOR>/2 = 3.3V
<RESISTOR>R1210</RESISTOR>/1 = 0.36V

It got correct resistance 1K Ohms.

Removed shield from J9600 and there was liquid as well and pins 44, 4, 6 looks affected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 19.5V 2.5A won't boot
threads.message:
Be sure no corrosion between J1800 pads.

Low level on <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> should be caused by SMC, or PCH.
In your case, can be accumulated crap underneath BGA chips, or some corroded, or broken resistor/trace.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 19.5V 2.5A won't boot
threads.message: It will safe to remove J9600? I think small part is melted).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 19.5V 2.5A won't boot
threads.message: You will need to bypass it with cables then...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 19.5V 2.5A won't boot
threads.message:
Cleaned board in ultrasonic cleaner and on both sides of <RESISTOR>R1210</RESISTOR> now got 3.3V

Board boot now but wont charge battery.
It shows 40% of charge so battery is visible by system but wont charge.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> without battery = 12.6V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> with battery = 11.6V

Is there any way to check if thats issue is on board or it need battery?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 19.5V 2.5A won't boot
threads.message:
Always best to check with known good battery in such case.
You may waste the time, even cause more damage on MLB, when the culprit is the battery.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 19.5V 2.5A won't boot
threads.message: All works fine with new battery - again... many many thanks for your help.
